commentText: C++  or Java is not outdated infact they are in demand. C/C++ is one of the toughest language and moderm systems  like telecom like 5G, Banking, Frameworks, networking related systems are coded in either C or C++. The problem itself is not about teaching C or C++ or Java and it is more about how it is teached often without practical inplementation. The problem with indian IT service sector company was around 40-50 persons doing petty jobs in support work. I have mostly worked in IT service companies only and if someone is doing coding or have domain level skills then he is still regarded..be it TCS or HCL or Infi. The problem began when employee started taking their job foregranted like working at 20-40% productivity, not learning any new things and demanding very high salary. I also think when the average salary in big tech service comes down then this firing will end. This is like consolidation and correction happening like in stock market and real estate.

commentText: More and more corporations/firms have found out that cutting costs raise profits faster than raising sales, so they find all kinds of ways to cut it. The easiest one they found recently, is to slowly cut down on employment because they only want the bare minimum level of employees, just enough to make the product work.  Problem comes when everyone starts doing that to raise their share value, since less people are employed sales drop, then they cut even more employees to make up that loss. The cycle then repeats until the market collapses one day, but the government refuses to step in, instead opting to double down and make it collapse earlier because they don't care if the US falls they just need to be in power after the fall.

commentText: Gonna be honest, the male nurses I have had were some of the best, most passionate, most understanding nurses I have ever met. And the ones that became ARNs and ARNPs were extremely good at listening to me and helping me form a solid plan and procedure. This isn't to say the female nurses are bad, but the men willing to deal with the stigma are the same that will work their tail off for the sake of being there for passion not paycheck. There are things culturally that male nurses and male patients can address that female nurses either aren't really exposed to or that the patient doesn't feel comfortable addressing with a female nurse.  I hate the stigma on both ends. Anyone going into a career should do it out of wanting to be there, not just because they need to optimize the paycheck and which government programs will reduce their long term debt.

commentText: It's not possible to complete the full Chartered Accountancy (CA) course in just one year. The CA course, including Foundation, Intermediate, and Final levels, typically takes a minimum of 4.5 to 5 years to complete. This includes the required articleship training period of three years. Even for graduates entering through the direct entry route, the minimum duration is 4.5 years.  Here's a more detailed breakdown:  Foundation Level: 6 months Intermediate Level: 8-10 months Articleship Training: 3 years Final Level: 6-12 months While some students might be able to accelerate their studies by studying intensely, passing exams quickly, and potentially completing the final level in one year after clearing the intermediate level, this would be an exception rather than the norm. The CA course requires a significant amount of time for theoretical learning,

videoTitle: Why Adulthood Became So Expensive
videoDescription: CNBC Marathon explores why young American adults today are struggling to settle down and make ends meet in the current ...
commentText: The idea of a starter home is just strange to me. It causes a lot of problems because people see houses as an asset that needs to maintain it's value rather than a lifelong place to live. This creates a lot of excesses like insane regulations to keep house values up. Also the idea of detached single family housing as the solution is insane to me as an European. It is environmentally disastrous, economically expensive to maintain as soon as the infrastructure starts to age  and results in essential services being far to reach and car dependency. If neighborhoods are dense and have a mixed use, taxes can go down because more people and businesses maintain it. If they are built right, life quality goes up as well. I always lived in areas like this, never had a car and always had most medical services, supermarkets, restaurants and other services such as schools, hairdressers, parks and shops in walking distance. These neighborhoods look friendly and are safe and look so much more inviting than the average dystopian American suburbs. There is a middle ground between single family housing and high rises that feels human sized and is very conductive to a healthy and social lifestyle.

commentText: In some ways, younger people might actually find it easier to get hired‚Äînot because opportunities are abundant, but because they‚Äôre more likely to accept vague promises, unpaid overtime, and the idea of a "bright future" that never quite arrives. videoTitle: Why Jobs Are Disappearing In The U.S.
videoDescription: Relatively few people are finding new jobs in the United States. The slowdown in hiring comes as businesses navigate rapidly ...
commentText: Another serious consequence of rapid AI adoption is the disappearance of entry-level positions ‚Äî the very roles people rely on to gain experience and grow into more advanced careers.  In many industries, AI systems are now handling tasks that used to be done by junior employees or interns. This creates a paradox: companies require experience for mid- and senior-level roles, but the entry-level jobs where that experience is usually gained are no longer available. As a result, new graduates and career-switchers are left with no real pathway to break into the field.  This issue is especially pronounced in tech and creative sectors, where automation and generative AI can already perform a wide range of tasks that were once assigned to beginners. If people can‚Äôt get that first job, they can‚Äôt build a portfolio, learn on the job, or advance in their profession. It becomes a closed loop ‚Äî one that excludes the next generation of talent before they even have a chance to start.  Long-term, this not only hurts individuals, but weakens entire industries by cutting off the supply of fresh minds and future experts.

videoTitle: Why Jobs Are Disappearing In The U.S.
videoDescription: Relatively few people are finding new jobs in the United States. The slowdown in hiring comes as businesses navigate rapidly ...
commentText: Learn from  Your history:  The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 did not work as intended because it led to a disastrous cycle of retaliatory tariffs from other countries. Rather than protecting American businesses, the act caused a sharp drop in international trade and deepened the economic hardships of the Great Depression.  Key reasons the Smoot-Hawley Tariff failed Sparked global trade wars In response to the U.S. raising tariffs on over 20,000 imported goods, foreign nations retaliated with their own tariffs on American products. Canada, the biggest U.S. trading partner at the time, was one of the first to respond with countermeasures. This cycle of "beggar-thy-neighbor" protectionism worsened the global economic crisis.  Caused international trade to plummet Between 1929 and 1934, global trade volumes shrank by approximately 65%. U.S. imports and exports to Europe fell by two-thirds from 1929 to 1932. The decline in exports was especially damaging to American farmers, who had already been struggling with overproduction and low prices.  Failed to help the U.S. economy The act's goal was to protect American industries and farmers, but the result was higher prices for American consumers at a time when purchasing power was already weak. The drop in exports contributed to bank failures and worsening unemployment, pushing the country deeper into the Depression.  Ignored warnings from economists More than 1,000 U.S. economists signed a petition urging President Herbert Hoover to veto the bill. However, Hoover signed the bill into law in June 1930, overriding the concerns of the experts.  Contributed to global political instability Beyond the immediate economic fallout, the Smoot-Hawley Act is seen by some historians as contributing to the rise of political extremism in other countries by destabilizing their economies.  Historical context and legacy The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act did not cause the Great Depression, which was already underway, but it is widely considered a major policy misstep that exacerbated the crisis. The act is a classic cautionary tale in modern economics, highlighting the dangers of protectionist trade policies and the interconnectedness of the global economy.

commentText: The same thing happened in Japan about 20 to 30 years ago. That generation is known as the ‚Äúemployment ice age‚Äù generation, and their incomes are clearly lower than those of other generations. Even though the population was large, many people in that cohort ended up in unstable or part-time jobs, which caused the birth rate to drop sharply and accelerated population decline.  Now the situation has gone too far in the opposite direction: because of the shrinking population, almost every workplace is suffering from labor shortages. People in their 20s and 30s are especially in high demand, and even those with no experience are trained closely and carefully.  Thirty years ago, companies were in a position to choose workers and often acted arrogantly. Today, it‚Äôs the other way around‚Äîyoung workers will simply say, ‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs the kind of company this is, goodbye,‚Äù and quit. As a result, companies have to be much more careful in how they train and treat employees.

videoTitle: Why Jobs Are Disappearing In The U.S.
videoDescription: Relatively few people are finding new jobs in the United States. The slowdown in hiring comes as businesses navigate rapidly ...
commentText: The rapid and widespread implementation of AI and automation in recent years has created a significant disruption in the global labor market. While these technologies were introduced under the promise of improving efficiency and reducing costs, the social and economic consequences have been largely underestimated ‚Äî or ignored altogether.  By replacing human labor at scale ‚Äî in everything from customer service to programming, logistics, and even creative work ‚Äî we've created a situation where millions of people are being pushed out of the workforce faster than new opportunities are being created. The result is not just higher unemployment, but also a shrinking consumer base. People without stable incomes cannot meaningfully participate in the economy, which undermines the very demand that companies rely on to sustain their operations.  Automation has certainly increased productivity in many sectors, but that increase has not translated into broad-based prosperity. Instead, it has concentrated profits in fewer hands while leaving large portions of the population economically insecure. This isn't just a technological issue ‚Äî it's a systemic one, where economic structures are not adapting fast enough to absorb the social impact of automation.  Without a balanced approach ‚Äî one that includes thoughtful regulation, reskilling programs, and policies that ensure people can still afford to live and participate in society ‚Äî we risk creating a cycle where efficiency gains actually weaken the economy rather than strengthen it.  AI and automation are powerful tools, but without a long-term vision and human-centered planning, they can do more harm than good.

commentText: The housing collapse was the first crack. Banks gambled, collapsed, and got taxpayer bailouts. Executives handed themselves bonuses with public money while the public paid the price. Occupy Wall Street tried to push back, but nothing truly changed. The same players stayed in power. The rules stayed rigged.  Now we are living through the next phase. Mass layoffs, ghost jobs, AI filters, and stagnant wages are everywhere. Profits soar, shareholders celebrate, and executives cash out while telling workers to be grateful for scraps.  Meritocracy is gone. Optics replaced it. Corporate success is no longer built on value or skill, but on who can perform the best image while cutting the people they parade for PR. Behind the curtain, the human element is gone, and the fa√ßade grows thicker.  AI is not the enemy. The real danger is AI CEOs and executives who treat technology as their personal crown. They are not building; they are competing to out-narcissist each other, blinded by ego and greed. Investors fuel this arms race because it spikes their portfolios, no matter the long-term damage. Behind closed doors, the C-suite and shareholders pat themselves on the back while carving out what remains of the middle class.  This is not about politics. It is about power. The ultra-wealthy control the levers and have no interest in building a system that works for anyone else. This is the second reckoning. The first was the manufacturing carve-out that gutted entire communities. This one is a technological carve-out, and its effects are already eroding the workforce from within.  If you feel invisible, you are not imagining it. This market is not broken; it is built to extract and discard. Until people stop accepting optics for progress and demand substance, the machine will keep grinding through generation after generation.  The ultra-wealthy will not save us. They are too busy competing to see who can burn it down the fastest.

commentText: I closed my laptop two minutes into an interview. Posted as remote, anywhere in my province. The interviewer asked how my day was going so far, I said something about the weather in my city that day. They froze, then said something about needing to be onsite (which was 4hrs away) once a week. I reminded her the posting only indicated remote work and she apologized for it being incorrect. I mentioned that I had another application pending for the same org, and wondered if she knew anything about the status of it. When I told her the position title, she told me it was a duplicate posting just worded slightly different. I told her there was a $35k difference between the two job listings. She froze again and I left the call shaking my head. That was one of only five interviews I got out of 70+ applications in a year.

commentText: I drove 45 minutes and showed up to a job interview and told the people at the front desk that I was here for an interview.  They looked confused and asked me for the name of the person I was supposed to be interviewing.  I gave them the name.  A little bit later, that person came out and we went into a private room to start talking.  They told me that the job was "recently filled" and there wasn't anything currently open anymore, but that they liked my resume enough that they wanted to talk to me in-person for "potential future opportunities".  At this point, I was seething so hard, I wanted to yell at them for wasting my time or say something snarky to this hiring manager.  But I practiced self control and played along and did my best as if the job was open, all the while rage was boiling in my stomach;  I didn't want to burn any bridges in-case this company is my last resort down the line and they do have something open in the far future.    But what a waste of my time, my whole day was wasted on this that could have been spent searching/applying for more jobs or preparing for a real interview.

The person I emailed my resume to is the same person who interviewed me and who is now my boss. commentText: Hearing to tailor the resume for each job posting, on top of already tailoring the cover letter for each job post, sounds fine in a small scale. But is unbelievably exhausting in reality. A lot of us applying to hundreds of jobs are doing that. It feels like it's just a pure numbers game rather than anything else. No matter how perfect a resume, cover letter, skills/abilities you have, experience history, etc., none of that seems to matter in the grand scheme of things. It's either you know someone, are able to know someone (and they're also willing to give you the time of day, which many aren't), or you have the willpower and patience to send out an infinite number of applications just for the hope of hearing back from a small few. Sorry if this sounds defeatist, I do appreciate the discussion and the advice, but this just eats away at you to where you just don't feel human anymore.

The federal government has purposefully crashed the economy to forestall entitlement reforms, tax reform, immigration reform, and industrial policy reform. Any reforms would risk uprooting entrenched financial positions so they‚Äôre crashing the economy instead. AI should be a boon for productivity but that can only happen during economic growth periods. So that‚Äôs why the AI is fundamentally useless. AI allows people to do more work to less knowledge, but when the government increases inflation by printing money while simultaneously making it more and more expensive to hire and import, we get an economic crash instead of an uptick in quality of life. By the end of 2028 there will be a full blown economic depression similar to 2008, or perhaps even worse.

commentText: it's the K shaped economy that's the root of all this. we let wealth inequality get so out of control that if the bottom 60% stopped all their consumer spending in its entirety, you'd only see a 20% reduction in purchases across the economy (a mild recession, but not catastrophic). at the same time, even a few % decrease in spending by the top 20% and the entire economy collapses. this has forced businesses and governments to create policy around that upper sector, and largely ignore the bottom 60% because, in economic terms, theyre irrelevant. theyre too poor and have too little purchasing power to cater to.   this is what happened in the 1880s-1920s, and it's happening again. the difference is today we can just replace the productive capacity of the bottom with automation. people really dont understand how bad this will get. even in the 1930s, despite massive government intervention, the economy never recovered. it took a world war to pull the US out of the slump, because a world war forced a redistribution of wealth (high taxes to pay for the war effort, followed by financial repression on those who own assets and a need for mass mobilization of the population which led to political concessions to guarantee cooperation) which reset the game. we're headed towards a feudalism with robots, or revolution. maybe both.

videoTitle: Why is the Job Market on the Brink of Collapse?
videoDescription: jobmarket #tech #techlayoffs The U.S.A job market is facing major strain as layoffs rise and automation accelerates. Despite ...
commentText: When a company wants 3-5 years of experience for an entry level job: 1. They aren't actually hiring. They're posting jobs pad the "jobs created" numbers. They're going to use it as leverage to say "they can't find qualified people" and pressure the government to allow them to hire more non-citizens on visa for cheaper (ex: the H1B visa program). OR, they're going to use it as an excuse for diving more into automation to justify replacing those jobs with AI and make someone at the company look good by "solving a problem" with AI.  2. They don't want people fresh out of school. You've all probably seen the BS reasons given for this. Look it up if you haven't, but there are companies that don't want to hire Gen Z workers fresh out of school right now. They often won't come out and say it because they don't want to spend money handling the backlash, but it's essentially what they're doing. As a reminder, age discrimination is LEGAL for anybody under 40. It's not until you hit age 40 and above that you now have a legal right against age discrimination in the US.  3. They're keeping wages down. Someone with 3-5 years of work experience is worth more than an entry level job salary, but if they can't get a higher position somewhere, they'll have to take the lower paying "entry level" position even if the "other duties as assigned" aspect of the job is actually something that would normally be done at a higher position. The reason why this is significant is because wages DO get tracked. Companies look at that data and think about ways they can squeeze more work out of every individual and if they can spread some work normally done by someone in a higher position among entry level workers to "give them experience" while keeping the amount they pay to get that work done lower, they consider it as "win/win". The bright eyed, eager entry level worker gets more exposure and experience and the company gets to pay less to get the work done. Now they can use AI to take more of the work load as well.  This isn't anything new. The same thing happened in the fallout of the dotcom bubble bust in the early 2000s. Younger GenX and older Millenials went through the same thing. Even before AI, people were writing software for automation. It IS unfair. It ruined those people's lives and prevented them from having a good start after school. Millions of people were screwed just by the timing of them entering the workforce. There was NO help for them. There will be NO help for GenZ entering the workforce today. In addition to that millions of other older workers had their careers destroyed as well. It was a dark time and then just as things showed signs of getting better, the Great Recession happened in the late 2000s.  Today, we're also heading to a major recession. It's a VERY bad sign when AI spending from few companies is literally propping up the US economy right now. The writing is on the wall. This situation may improve somewhat for a few people who finally break into the workforce, but a recession is coming to knock them and everyone else down.  I REALLY wish there was a better outlook coming, but there isn't. All any of us can do (young and older workers alike) is keep on trying. Giving up won't pay the bills or put food on the table. After we get through the coming dark times, things will eventually get better for everyone, but we have to keep trying and sometimes fight to get there.

commentText: This is not the deeper underlying root of the chaos unraveling in the job market though. Yes, companies are reporting record profits while job growth is stagnant ‚Äî but the real issue goes deeper. With real-time analytics and constant quarterly-report pressure, executives are fixated on hitting KPIs every 90 days instead of building anything long-term.  So the ‚Äústrategy‚Äù becomes layoffs, cost-cutting, and efficiency pushes ‚Äî because that‚Äôs the only reliable way to churn higher profits. They‚Äôre not generating those profits through innovation or sustained growth; they‚Äôre squeezing the organization to make the numbers look good.  And now that AI can replace a lot of lower-level work, I don‚Äôt know if this cycle ever reverses. We‚Äôve identified the problem, but I‚Äôm not convinced the old job market ever comes back.

commentText: Why does everyone always leave out the major DUST and WIND when they discuss Vegas? It ain't only the damn heat buddy. Also, you left out the following drawbacks:  1. High azz car insurance, it doubles when you come from Los Angeles, and then  it goes up from there even without any tickets or accidents.  2. Speaking of insurance, you also left out the DUI's there in Vegas, that is a big factor in why insurance is so high.  3. The water in Vegas is super hard, expect to either have dry skin or use a lot of lotion.  4. NO, Vegas is NOT completely diversified. Sure there are other players there, and it is better than before, but at the end of the day gambling and casinos are the biggest drivers in the city. That means it is very dependent on tourism. As you see right now, when gambling and tourism goes down, so does everything else in that city.  5. People like to point out there is no state taxes...Let me yell this, SO WHAT. By the time Vegas is done FEEING your azz to death, no wonder they don't have any state taxes, they get that money in other ways. In fact, the fees on the strip is said to be KILLING the strip. Them fees don't stop there, residents also pay fees for living in Nevada. Now there are instances where residents are cut some slack, like free or discounted parking on the strip if you have ID. But FEES are awful.  And when it comes to the good things in Vegas, for me it is that no matter where you live, everyone is no more than 40 minutes from each other. Nobody lives farther than 35 minutes from the airport.

commentText: In addition to all your outdoor recreations, you missed a big one -- Off-roading, 4x4, etc.  Hundreds of miles of trails on Bureau of Land Management land even around Vegas in Clark County, camping for the weekend wherever you want, we have the darkest skies in the nation for those that want to look up even an hour outside of town.  For those with OHV (off highway vehicles, dune buggies etc) we have the dunes just north of the Air Force Base.  Off Highway races.... and even sanctioned on-highway races like SSCC.      Fun fact: Nevada has 600 ghost-towns to explore (Rhyolite is still in amazing condition) for those looking to the past and how we got to be known the Silver State.  Sports... we're getting sports teams, not just pro hockey and football, but we have WNBA, Pro Lacrosse, Pro Volleyball, Pro Arena Football (I forget what else is in Henderson) and a AAA Minor League Baseball team in Summerlin.       What we (and the LVMPD) need to work on is getting better traffic enforcement, better license plate enforcement.  Too many people keep their Cali tags or drive dirty with no tags and Metro don't give a flip.   DUI and bad driving is rampant, insurance rates are through the roof, uninsured, underinsured motorists outweigh the responsible ones  Everyone leaves everywhere, Vegas isn't immune.  It's not for everyone.  But wow I haven't gone a day without smiling since I got here, best decision ever.

commentText: Overall a good video, but a couple of points I would like to add:  1) While yes, the unemployment rate is currently at about 4%, that doesn‚Äôt accurately reflect how many people are unemployed. It just says how many people, who are eligible for unemployment benefits, are actually receiving unemployment. If you quit your job (due to a toxic work environment), did not seek unemployment, gave up certifying for unemployment, your unemployment ran out, or otherwise didn‚Äôt qualify for unemployment / currently on unemployment but are still an adult before the retirement age who isn‚Äôt currently working, you aren‚Äôt counted towards the unemployment rate. That said, even if we assume that rate is twice as high (like 8% the eligible working population) which is overly generous, the point in the video still stands, but that would help explain why (1) it‚Äôs hard to get a job and (2) the perception of others without jobs being fairly high.  2) The unemployment cycle is extremely real. In addition to what‚Äôs mentioned in the video head hunters and job recruiters extremely favor those who are currently working than those who aren‚Äôt. They often assume that those who are unemployed lost their job because they‚Äôre incompetent, or not good to work with, and that they‚Äôre currently unemployed because they‚Äôre lazy. Furthermore, the longer you‚Äôre unemployed, the bigger the gap in your resume is making you easier to pass over by recruiters. Do what he says in the video and everything you do while unemployed in terms of training and self development, put it in your resume to fill the gap. It makes you look like you weren‚Äôt sitting on your thumbs just waiting for the next job to fall into your lap.  3) You can do everything right and still be unemployed for 6 months - 1.5 years. It sucks, but you have to remember it‚Äôs a numbers game and that this is ultimately a matter of luck (in essentially being in the right place at the right time). All you can do is increase your odds (and this video does do a good job at telling you how to do that), but be aware that you aren‚Äôt alone, and others have been in this situation you‚Äôre in or are currently going through it themselves. As he says, just keep at it (it‚Äôs all you can do at the end of the day anyway).

commentText: 1:02 Yeah unemployment in US is roughly around 4.2%, but you need to take for consideration that it doesn't represent people you advertise this video to - which are young adults. For that statistic you would rather take youth (16-24) unemployment rate, that consists of high school/student graduates. The youth unemployment rate is 9.7%, which have grown almost percent since the last month. Especially the AI growth have played huge difference in the IT industry, where companies don't need to hire young candidates, cause the easy task can be done by AI. The market has also been over-saturated of IT students/workers and it will only be harder for them to get into IT. I've been a specialist in certain IT field for 2 years, got my job eliminated in company and couldn't find a job similiar to that for half a year. And to be fair no side projects would make my situation any better, when my expierience wasn't even taken into consideration.

commentText: To any job seekers reading this comment: don‚Äôt give up on online job applications. It is very true that online job boards are in a bad state right now. Fake job listings, thousands of applicants, and companies using ai to deny resumes, not to mention having to make online accounts for every company that uses workday among other pains that you are no doubt aware of. But I assure you in the sea of thousands of job listings there is one out there for you. I recently secured a job with a company that uses workday after months of applying and almost calling it quits. I know how bad the struggle is but you should never stop applying. But most importantly don‚Äôt just apply to every job you think is a good fit for you. Make sure your resume and cv are tweaked so hr or the hiring manager can understand what you could bring to the job.

commentText: I live in St Petersburg Florida, which has seen unprecedented migration from all over the country. It went from being a sleepy little town to a packed metropolis. Despite that, at the same time every business is closing, cutting hours or laying people off. A Wendy's just closed, a Checkers just closed. Village Inn cut hours, IHOP cut hours. The local ice cream shop that's been around since the 60s closed, the local burger place that's been open since the 60s closed. Home Shopping Network closed. For the first time since the 1970s we don't have a 24-hour or even late night grocery store. I know people with multiple college degrees who have been looking for a job for the past 6 months with no luck. There are homeless people everywhere. When I do ride sharing I take people with full-time jobs home to efficiency apartments, trailer parks and motel rooms.  The average studio apartment is over $2,000. I'm pretty sure that there's a crash coming any moment now.

commentText: I have applied to over 300 jobs since beginning of July 2025. Ive had maybe 10 call backs for interviews. commentText: Hey Michael, here's my opinion on unemployment rate: Its an acute figure that only reflects recently laid off workers within the past 2-3 months at a given point in time.  In reality it is much, much, worse.  Basically, the unemployment pipeline is: Get laid off without any cause provided, the state gives you unemployment benefit.   Apply for thousands of fake indeed  tax-write-off listing jobs per week to document in order to receive said benefit.  After 3 months of not hearing back from anyone your unemployment benefit runs out.  Either give up or doordash, either way, the government no longer considers you unemployed.

commentText: It's good to have multiple trade skills like plumbing, electrician, HVAC, roofer, framer, painter, landscaping, road paver, machanic, nursing, etc. That way you can pivot to the jobs that are in demand when your job goes away. My mistake was I didn't invest in myself and didn't learn multiple skills until I was laid off this year. Right now I am learning to be an electrician and it's going to take another 8 months to finish. I would recommend to anyone that is employed at a single job, go and get certified in other fields while you have the opportunity. It will be less stressful than when you have to work minimum wage job, do a side hustle, and learn a new skill.

commentText: The economy is suffering due to poor fundamentals.  These include the overall phenomenon called "structural unemployment."  Some economists have predicted this for decades because of its Malthusian essence.  Too many people, not enough jobs.  It will never return to what was.  It's not part of normal economic cycles that the experts are so fond of citing. It's exacerbated by AI and robotics.  Unless the government was proactive in planning to make society more socialistic, and improving conditions for citizens, then it's a down hill slide towards a plutocracy. Unfortunately that's the widening chasm between the rich and the poor, leaving the mid-class in tatters trying to maintain their standard of living in a country where the average person is involved in a non-consensual relationship with an economy hell bent on fleecing the shit out of people.  The automobile is the biggest fraud ever perpetrated on a populace. Just add up all the costs inherent in the operation of your car and hang up and drive.  The fender bender industry wants you on your phone, with headlights unique to each model and absurd prices for injection molded parts with insane margins. Back to the acyclic economic milieu in which we exist.  The end of the petroleum age means that we are seeing prices rise based on a truer calculation of embedded costs.   The slow death of urban core retail means that commercial real estate is getting shitty, and that sector has anchored funds and such for years.   Bankers are slow to adjust. Every company is squeezing everything for revenue, meaning the firings and the terrible job market are the tip of the iceberg. The guy who got voted in isn't doing anything to help you folks that believed the rhetoric.  He just wants to aggrandize himself and his cronies by reviving the polluting of our country while bad mouthing renewable energy because of its effect on the "landscape."   Since when has he given a shit about the natural world? Has he visited an open pit mine recently.  He has doubled his net worth over the last 6-18 months, while most US citizens are suffering.   Make no mistake: He doesn't give a shit about any of us, unless you're part of the war machine dominated by the Big 5 and go to Davos or Tetons.   Over Easter he dismissed us all and said "just enjoy your life" in a display of such callous indifference the average person's plight as to be obscene. He has begun to take away the basic right to free speech and his attacks on people smarter than he is who criticize what is happening is truly frightening.  We should all be very concerned and petition our generally greedy representatives who are often focused on their own inside information making their assisted stock market picks way easier. Stop attacking people who you might call liberal and understand that it will require all of us to find accord and quorum to achieve any progress.   Infighting and factionalism will be our downfall.

After doing my own thing, I am now creating c++ apps, have hired some work out, and have attracted new job offers (sorry but I'm going for gold now). Pursue your craft and jobs will become a side hustle to earn some cash.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I've come to the conclusion that I no longer want to chase after a language or framework. This changes all the time. I've also decided that I will no longer subject myself to being treated like a commodity at a cattle auction. In the end, all of this is designed to make you accept doing more for less. I think at some point we give in and accept unrealistic things because the "market demands it," or the influencer you follow or the group of followers in the bubble you're in dictates that this is the culture, technology, or method to be adopted. Yes, I went through a financial setback and had to accept working in other segments. But that didn't kill my desire to work with software. Today, I think the path is to work as an entrepreneur and consultant for small businesses, creating solutions for the region you live in or where you can work without creating a burden on your life. Another mistake I see is the industrialization of the IT workforce. We didn't start that way; we started in a garage or on a small project; we're not cattle.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I worked in tech for 45 years in several roles. When I started, ‚ÄúBeing in computers.‚Äù, was like saying you were a Wizard in a tower. Your job was mysterious and magical and few others were in the industry competing for these enchanted positions. I retired a few years ago.  Nowadays, computer techs are a commodity and the perception is of an office worker. You are disposable and can be replaced in days from thousands of other candidates in your field. You‚Äôre no more important than a file clerk.  I worked through the tech industry‚Äôs best years and retired (age 60) at the tail end of that time.  Best of luck but it‚Äôs going to be a crap shoot and the jobs are pretty harsh.

commentText: I'm sorry the market is so brutal.  I would suggest, in the meantime, code your own apps for sale in the app store.  Doing this will achieve a few powerful things: (1) keep your skills fresh, (2) create something to show off, (3) potentially make some good money on the sale of your apps, and (4) keep your mind sharp, fresh.  You can also use this time to achieve certifications.  At the end of the day, give major consideration in the idea of working for yourself, building your own solutions.

commentText: The tech market isn't cooked, SWE jobs are cooked.  Lots of people don't realize there's so many other technical jobs out there to apply for. Look into Solution Engineer/Solutions Consultant roles, or Implementation Consultant, or Integration Specialist.  I went the implementation Consultant route, my current role only had 100 applicants in 2 weeks, meanwhile SWE jobs get 1000 applicants in 2 days.  I know it's easy to feel doomed but there are sooo many paths out there guys. I wouldn't even be surprised if I find myself as a SWE one day.

commentText: Sometimes you have to pivot into a different field.  Back in 96 I was 32 years old with a newly printed MBA.  I thought I would go far in the financial industry.  Instead I was laid off with many others.  After over 6 months with no job in sight it was my mom who suggested I become a substitute teacher at the local school district.  I took the advice because I had bills to pay.  Near the end of the school year I was asked if I wanted to sign a contract for the upcoming school year as an emergency credential special education teacher.  This would require me going to school at night while teaching during the day.  I accepted the offer once again bills to pay and would get covered under their health insurance.  My thinking was that I would just stay long enough until the economy improved.  I found out I enjoyed teaching and I am now 6 months away from retiring with 30 years and a very generous pension.  As stated earlier sometimes you have to pivot into something new......

videoTitle: Unemployed Americans express doubt about finding a job
videoDescription: CBS Evening News‚Äù reports on unemployed Americans looking for work in an uncertain job market. 00:00 Unemployed woman ...
commentText: Tired of the "automation won't replace humans, but work with them" nonsense. Entry-level today, mid/late career tomorrow, C-suite the next day. Starting with the great decoupling in the 1970s, human labor has been and will continue trending to zero. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY. Automation and robotics will necessarily replace human workers due to the current economic system. Today, AI is the WORST it will ever be going forward. It DOESN'T MATTER if AI "creates" 200 million new jobs...AI will solve and execute these new "jobs" much faster than humans will be able to adapt, learn, and fill them. Capital/employee model-it worked great...for quite a while. However, now companies that automate lower their costs, become more competitive. Those that keep higher-cost human labor necessarily fall behind and will go out of business. This creates a system where replacing people with machines is not just likely, but necessary for company survival. There is a way to deal with this humanely, but it would require a full revamp of the social contract and our concept of work. Even capitalists will want this change when unemployment reaches a tipping point and there‚Äôs no one left with money to buy the crap they‚Äôre selling.  I know, LLMs are leveling off, "what about the energy?," blah, blah, blah. Do not conflate LLMs with AI. LLMs are no more AI than vacuum tubes are computers or AOL dial-up is the internet. So, LLMs are leveling off. History shows technological advance is not just one sigmoid curve. It's a series of sigmoid curves with each successive one reaching new capabilities and new heights. To think that after 200,000 years, this pattern is all the sudden going to stop is absurd. I also understand there will be new jobs for humans created, it will go in this pattern: Automation creates 5 new jobs this year, lays off 30; creates 5 new jobs next year, lays off 500; creates 5 new jobs the following year, lays off 1500 etc. In the macro economic picture, do you not see this as an issue? I also understand there is more opportunity for entrepreneurs. Again, from the macro perspective there is a MINORITY of people that have the entrepreneurial ability/spirit. It takes that, and a strong majority of people don't have it.  Reasoning AI Is the Next Big Leap. The future of AI is not just about generating answers, but about ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù breaking down complex problems step-by-step, more like a human brain. Breakthroughs like DeepSeek‚Äôs open-source reasoning models are already being incorporated into platforms like GPT and xAI, marking a shift toward more advanced, thoughtful AI. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY.  There‚Äôs a persistent and misleading narrative circulating often perpetuated by short term goal-driven institutions like politicians, universities, and tech company executives, that the future of work is secure. The claim goes: ‚ÄúYou just need to learn how to work with AI,‚Äù and humans collaborating with AI will outperform either one alone. But recent research, including a landmark study from the University of Virginia, tells a different story. In diagnosing medical conditions, AI alone achieved far greater accuracy than either human doctors or even doctors assisted by AI. The median diagnostic accuracy for the docs using Chat GPT Plus was 76.3%, while the results for the physicians using conventional approaches was 73.7%. Sounds like ‚Äúa win‚Äù at first. However, Chat GPT Plus alone achieved a median diagnostic accuracy of more than 92%. In other words, the comforting idea that humans will always be essential partners to machines is crumbling. In many fields, AI is not just a tool, it is the superior performer. This has staggering implications for the future of work, especially to the often used solution of prior technological displacement that go ‚ÄúYou just need to be retrained.‚Äù To the group advocating the "retraining solution," I pose to you this: You have a medical doctor, just finished 8 years of higher education, a low-paid 4-year internship/residency, is hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt, and just got outperformed by automation; what would you have this doctor retrained into that will offer a secure job?  The result of this, since the United States' moronic system is based on taxing employees for about 70% of all tax revenue, this will further exacerbate the problem. Tax needs to be based on what's going on now and in the future not what worked 75 years ago. Oh I know it's so evil to think, but we might need to tax the companies who are doing the automation. Even if you do that, it's a win-win. For instance say a company had 1,000 employees in automated away down to 100. 1,000 employees paid federal taxes, including payroll tax, of about 20 million a year. Now the 100 people pay about 2 million a year. However, by automating, the company sees two things: they are no longer paying approximately 60 million in wages and their share of payroll tax, AND since nobody automates to lose money they also have higher profits. What's so wrong about taxing that company for the $60 million dollars they don't have to pay anymore and a fair percentage of their additional profits they now make through the automation. Not all the additional profits, but some of them. If you do that there's a higher tax revenue and more profits for the company. That's a win-win for the government and for businesses. If humanity, as a whole, weren't so stupid, we would just adjust as tech progresses to where EVERYONE benefits somewhat from each stage and just move smoothly into the post-labor economy.  To understand this shift, consider the historical role of the horse and oxen. They were once essential to the economy as sources of power for agriculture, transport, and industry. Technologies like the horse collar and the steel plow dramatically increased their output, making them even more valuable. But then came the steam engine and, later, the internal combustion engine. These machines didn‚Äôt just help the horse, but outperformed it entirely. Trains, tractors, and trucks could do the job ten, even a hundred times faster and more powerfully. And from that moment forward, the horse was no longer critical to economic output. It was, in essence, unemployed.  This is what AI and robotics are doing to human labor. They are not simply replacing the repetitive or the physical; they are increasingly outperforming humans in cognition, strategy, design, and communication. And just like the horse, our value in the economic system will diminish, not from lack of talent or effort, but because machines will do the job better. That‚Äôs why we need to start thinking not in terms of retraining, but about restructuring society itself for a world where human labor is no longer essential to production. When the very essence of what makes an entity useful to the current economy is superseded (be that strength, endurance, dexterity, analysis, creativity, empathy, intelligence, persuasion as well as many other qualities) that entity becomes irrelevant to economic output.  Potential solution. Decentralized AI Ownership: A Bridge Toward Post-Scarcity. While Universal Basic Income (UBI) may serve as an initial economic stopgap, bridging today‚Äôs economy with tomorrow‚Äôs abundance consider an even more equitable and long-term solution: Decentralizing the ownership of artificial intelligence itself.   Rather than concentrating the power of AI in the hands of a few corporations or governments, envision a model where AI entities are open-source and collectively owned. This could take the form of assigning each person a digital "share" of an AI system, not unlike a stakeholder‚Äôs share in a company. As the AI produces value, whether through intellectual labor, creative output, or autonomous economic participation, those shares would generate dividends distributed directly to individuals.   This model would ensure that as AI becomes the dominant productive force in society, the wealth it creates is shared universally, not monopolized. It aligns with the principle that the fruits of public knowledge made possible by centuries of human collaboration should benefit everyone, not just a few early adopters or private entities. In practice, this could look like:   - AI systems running Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) that distribute profits algorithmically. - Smart contracts ensuring transparent, equitable income flows based on collective stake. - Global ‚ÄúAI cooperatives‚Äù where users vote on how AI is used, improved, and deployed. - Universal basic compute.   If AI becomes the primary driver of economic output, then equitable access to its benefits isn‚Äôt just fair, it‚Äôs necessary to avoid deepening inequality and instability. It provides a scalable, technologically aligned extension to UBI, ensuring people not only have income, but true economic participation in the age of intelligent machines.   Ultimately, decentralized AI ownership may be the last transition phase before full post-scarcity, when advanced technologies like universal nanofactories or matter compilers render even economic structures obsolete. Until then, however, models like this offer a way to reclaim agency in a world where production no longer requires human hands, and where wealth can, for the first time in history, truly be universal.

commentText: I almost got scammed by a fake remote job. They wanted to interview but not with the Webcam. I said this feels scammy directly to them and that if they can't verify themselves then I'm not interested. They just said we're not a scam but if you feel like that then you don't have to work for us. That's some crazy stuff to say for a "non-scam" job. Sadly though they have my first name and number. The CRAZY part, it only happened because I had to put my information on the California government employment service for edd and they scam job said they found my resume on there. Like damn. And the scammer was impersonating a real person and company. Like they are doing due diligence. If I wasn't a victim of scams before, I probably well fell for it because it sounded like a good job but if there's one lesson I want to tell other's, if it sounds too good to be true, it probably is a scam or there's some catch. It IS too good to be true. It IS a scam.

commentText: This is a great video and I applaud all of you for your efforts.  I know it's very hard for younger people in this market and I'm not trying to dispute that for a second.  The part your discussion didn't cover was older workers.  I was laid off after an acquisition in 2019 (at 58) after a successful career with a mid-market company as an IT leader.  Just before COVID hit.  Instead of the entry level job that requires 5 yrs experience, I got ghosted hundreds of times for SR leadership roles that I was VERY qualified for while I watched my life savings disappear.  TBH, I never found another job...and at this point...I don't want one.  I decided to put my software development skills to work and started building companies.  That has been a LONG, hard journey over the last 6 years, with extremely limited results as I didn't try to make quick easy money, but rather to build apps that I would be proud of.  We're very close to taking off and I look forward to being part of the solution rather than the problem.  In other words, I want to hire good people affected by this BS and build a company with a difference.  Good luck to you all!  I'm heading off to sign the petition.

videoDescription: Landlords are aggressively cutting rents in late 2025, a warning that the housing market and economy could be heading towards ...
commentText: Declining rents mean one thing for the U.S. Housing Market: deflation.  When you see rents dropping at the same time homebuyer demand is at 30-year lows, it signals a deep and persistent demand problem. That weakness is now showing up across the country ‚Äî rents are falling, price cuts are rising, and more markets are entering outright decline.  For renters and first-time buyers, this is great news. It means 2026 is shaping up to be the most affordable year in housing since before the pandemic.  The downside? This is a brutal environment for investors and landlords. Rents are falling across the once-booming Sun Belt, compressing yields at the same time taxes and insurance keep climbing. Investors are selling more, buying less, and re-evaluating their portfolios.  But there are still opportunities. In the video, I broke down my top 3 most affordable markets heading into 2026 ‚Äî places where you can still buy a home or rental for $1,000/month or less on your mortgage payment (including taxes).  To find more markets where the numbers still work, go to www.reventure.app and upgrade to the premium package. commentText: When you look at all the measures of the labor market, not just the headline unemployment rate, things look very bad out there. A dropping labor force participation rate, which means that there are an increasing number of people who could work but aren't able to for many months or even years. Dropping wages and salaries in many disciplines. Underemployment (where people with college and even graduate degrees are doing work that high-school dropouts could do) is up. Non-discretionary expenses like rent, utilities, health insurance, loan payments, and even the simplest food options are up. Most of the job ads are faked. Most job applications never see a human's eyes.  And by all appearances, this is exactly what both corporate leaders and government leaders *want*.

videoTitle: how we‚Äôre *actually* getting jobs in 2025 #jobsearch
commentText: I think it‚Äôs not a one size fits all for people. This is a little too type a for me. I recommend getting a bridge job that can float you a few months so you are not applying from desperation. Nannying, Uber, restaurant work, anything that you could do and not be miserable. Once you have some money flowing in, apply to the jobs that you absolutely love. Redo your resume so it tells the story you want to tell. Sometimes when you are just living life and not desperate for resources the right connections, resources, and opportunities pop up. Good luck!

The big job boards are way too saturated with applicants and AI is filtering out most of the apps so they‚Äôre not even seen. If you‚Äôre applying for hundreds and hundreds of jobs and hearing nothing back obviously something isn‚Äôt working and you should change your tactic

videoTitle: how we‚Äôre *actually* getting jobs in 2025 #jobsearch
commentText: You may get bites from very small firms. For larger firms, this is worse than contacting recruiter directly. Interviewing screening and such are usually side things for hiring managers and are more focused on their primary senior job duties. They will more than likely get annoyed and ignore it completely. Especially these days where applicant to role ratios are wack. Chances are they already have dozens of folks contacting them directly.  Networking helps a lot: job fairs, friends, family, hobby groups. Have multiple people look over your resume. Practice interviewing. Other than that it's a number game.

commentText: I graduated in May this year with a BBA in finance and have been applying to all finance and accounting jobs. I‚Äôve had a few interviews. But no job offer. I even reached out to alumni and employees in the industry on LinkedIn. But they rarely reply back and when they do, they just repeat the same advice and say how they‚Äôll reach out if their company will hire. These past 4 months have been the worst months of my life. Legit can‚Äôt fall asleep at night because of worry of being unemployed and not being able to pay bills on time or support myself. I‚Äôve had multiple emotional outbursts and panic attacks in my room where I broke my ps5 controller in half randomly and even tore my shirt off my body once. All because of not getting a chance from the hundreds of jobs I applied and interviewed at. College was a joke and I regret wasting four years of my life there smh. For now I‚Äôm just going to apply to fast food and retail jobs until I figure my life out. If I don‚Äôt have a career in finance or accounting by the end of 2026 or first few months of 2027, I‚Äôm joining the military because F this and F life at this point smh.

commentText: As a Recruiter who was working with Big Tech until April this year, I can tell you that a lot of times companies close the jobs from their end on the Applicant tracking systems. But jobs continue to show because 1] there is a sync error/lag between the system and the various job portals integrated with it. So jobs remain published on portals even though the company is no longer accepting applications. 2] Several job portals/aggregators keep reposting old/expired job ads to attract candidates and expand their databases. They lure candidates with free to create accounts. Then, they sell this database to company recruiters. Bigger the database, higher the price. They don't care whether jobs shown are legit. As an aggregator, their liability is limited.

commentText: When of the biggest challenges is staying current with your skills. Software and platforms are undergoing generational changes every year. If you are out of the market for 6 months, there may  no longer be a need for your skill set. You couldn't even qualify for the job you left as they are using newer or at least upgraded platforms.  This is extremely stressful and frustrating to someone who is just trying to get a toe hold in the market and stay there. One thing not talked about much is that so much of this work is now done through contractors and vendors. You get a 6 month contract, you're nearing the end of it so you start looking for your next gig. Recuiters don't need you in 3 weeks at the end of your contract. They need you today. That job posting wont even be there when your contract ends. This virtually guarantees periods of unemployment.

videoTitle: Will The Tech Job Market Ever Recover?
videoDescription: Mass layoffs, automation, and deceptive hiring practices have left hundreds of thousands of tech workers unemployed. Fake job ...
commentText: Current Challenges in the Tech Job Market Massive Layoffs: Over 260,000 tech jobs were cut globally in 2023, followed by 150,000+ in 2024 and 25,000+ in 2025.  Automation Impact: Nearly 50% of executives report increased automation, replacing mid-level engineering and administrative roles.  Fake Job Listings: 55% of tech companies post fake job ads, with 70% of recruiters considering it acceptable.  Low Interview Rates: Only 8% of tech job applicants receive interview responses, down from 12% in previous years.  Corporate Ghosting: Many applicants receive no response even after multiple interview rounds.  Longer Job Searches: The average time to secure a tech job in the U.S. has risen from 3 to 5+ months.  Mental Health Strain: Endless rejections and ghosting have led to widespread frustration among job seekers.  Decline in Entry-Level Roles: Entry-level tech job postings dropped by 30% in the UK and over 70% for software developers in the U.S. (2023-2025).  Rising Unemployment: IT sector unemployment reached 5.5% in May 2025, surpassing the national average.  Shifts in Hiring and Job Demand AI-Driven Job Growth: AI-related roles (machine learning, data science, cloud computing) are growing despite declines in traditional tech jobs.  Changing Skill Requirements: Companies now prioritize practical certifications over traditional degrees.  Fewer General IT Jobs: Tech support and generic software engineering roles are shrinking.  New Job Creation: AI is generating demand for specialized roles (AI scientists, cybersecurity experts, data architects).  Struggles for New Graduates: Unemployment for recent graduates is at 7%, the highest in a decade, with 30-40% fewer entry-level openings.  Visa Challenges: Over 10,000 H1B visa holders lost jobs in 2023, with many struggling to find new placements.  Future Projections & Recovery Selective Recovery: The job market is rebounding slowly but unevenly, favoring niche AI and automation-related roles.  18% Growth in Tech Jobs: The U.S. Department of Labor predicts 350,000+ new tech jobs annually by 2034, mostly in AI and cybersecurity.  No Return to Pre-2022 Levels: The market won‚Äôt regain its 2021-2022 hiring peaks; instead, it will become more specialized.  Permanent Structural Changes: Mass hiring and extravagant perks are fading as companies prioritize efficiency and automation.  Adaptation Required: Job seekers must upskill in AI, cloud computing, and cybersecurity to remain competitive.

commentText: A trifecta of labor market readings just hit‚Äîand they all suggest a recession may already be underway:  ADP: 32,000 job losses in September  Indeed: Job openings index now back to pre-pandemic levels (-35% from peak)  BLS: Hiring rate has fallen to the lowest level since 2008‚Äì09  When three independent sources line up like this, it‚Äôs hard to ignore. Something is clearly breaking under the surface.  But here‚Äôs the twist: layoffs are still historically low, so the unemployment rate hasn‚Äôt moved much. At the same time, GDP growth and stock prices are still high. That‚Äôs why it doesn‚Äôt feel like a recession yet.  The impact I‚Äôm watching most closely is on housing. As job losses pick up and more households are forced to sell, housing demand will crack further. We‚Äôre already seeing a housing recession in half the U.S.‚Äîwith values dropping in places like Florida, Texas, and Arizona. The question is: how long before the pain spreads to other states?  üëâ Head to Reventure App  to track the data in your ZIP code. Pay close attention to inventory‚Äîif it‚Äôs spiking in your market, that‚Äôs a leading sign the recession is already underway, and cheaper home prices could be just around the corner. commentText: Employers want you to be afraid‚Äîafraid of losing your job, of not being able to make rent‚Äîbut the truth is, they depend on that fear. They want you to feel replaceable and insignificant, yet if every American worker quietly resolved in their hearts that work is no longer a viable path forward, the valuations of the ruling class‚Äôs assets would collapse. If nobody can afford anything, nothing has real value.  This is the great secret the elites will never want you to know: alone, we are a drop in the bucket; together, we are something they cannot survive. And they know it. They escalate their cruelty to intimidate us‚Äîbut fewer and fewer are afraid. When you have nothing to lose, you become fearless.  "Beware; for I am fearless, and therefore powerful."

commentText: Interesting data on the job market as it shows Therapists leading with job growth. I'm a Licensed Psychotherapist in California and for the past 10 years I have tried to convince a few family/friends to get in the field. We enter the job market around $85k and at 5 years around $140k. I've been a therapist 16 years and can easily clear $200k+ all from the comfort of my home, thanks to covid forcing insurance companies to offer therapy via video. I encourage anyone who has a passion for helping others to consider the field. As long as there are people breathing, we will always be needed, and Ai cannot replace therapists or psychiatric evaluations. The ONLY downside, 9 years of schooling and clinical rotations to become an independent Licensed Psychotherapist, but it's definitely worth it!

Consumers are spending more but buying less that's why it appears that consumers are ignoring inflation. They just have to keep paying more for the things they need to buy. I think if you look at it by category that discretionary spending is down for everyone but the very wealthy. The very wealthy are spending more because their wealth keeps going up. That spending at the very top is also making this look like average consumers are better off then they are.

videoTitle: The U.S. Recession is finally here.
videoDescription: ADP just released a shocking job market report, showing that employers shed 32000 jobs in September, signaling that we are ...
commentText: The Stock market is driven by one thing: index funds / 401(k) plans.  It is the check box on your payroll.  Most people are doing the "smart thing" and checking "put my 401k into an index fund."  It is like a steamroller that does not care what the market does or what the fundamentals are doing.  It is DUMB MONEY.  I can only imagine what the pension managers are thinking as they have spent all that payroll money on an already inflated market and huge bubble.  At some point, when the number of people unemployed grows and the funding stream has less money, the redemptions will exceed the incoming funds, and we are all in for a trillion-dollar disaster.  Like the student loan fiasco brought to you by Congress, which removed the bankruptcy option, this mess is also of congressional making.

commentText: Yeah, senior engineer here.  I just finished work at 9PM tonight.  I started at 8AM, skipped lunch and breakfast and took a 10m break because my legs were falling asleep.  Tomorrow I will get to do it all over again and nobody is going to notice the extra work I put in.  The management will say, "take a break", but they are not going to put the pipeline on hold or say the bugs can wait so even taking a day off fills you with anxiety because you know your project just slipped.  Is that worth 6 figures? Maybe 25 years ago when I first entered the industry.  I love to code, and the tech today is so exciting, but I have missed so much of life because of it.  Now my goal is just to make enough so I can retire early and spend time with my family.  The vast majority though is not people quitting, it's people who are being laid off.  Why? Outsourcing.  Some will say AI, but I think that is just the scapegoat, we all know it can't really do engineering yet.

commentText: The big tech only perspectives kind of get tiring after a while and make me realize how much of a bubble these workers actually reside in. Not everyone who works as a developer works in big tech, or has a desire to work in big tech. In fact, I would say THE VAST MAJORITY of developers do not work in big tech. Literally every industry (and probably every company) has a need for developers/technical workers. Instead of whining about how tough things are and quitting the industry entirely because 5 companies treat their employees like numbers, try one of the other thousands of mid to small size companies in pretty much any industry you find interesting. I think people who do this would discover that:  1. You are likely more valued when the company isn't a large tech company, and your immediate team is smaller 2. You have more to offer in helping that particular company grow 3. Benefits (and pay) can be just as good in smaller more established companies 4. More control over the projects you work on and less stress in general 5. You have higher flexibility in how you choose to work 6. A lot more leverage in terms of what you want because they desperately will not want you to leave if you are the go-to person. They aren't going to replace the only person who knows anything about development with AI.   Find a small to medium size family-oriented company (not a chaotic start-up), make an immediate impact, be treated like a person rather than a number, pursue your passions and hobbies and all the other crap with the time and sanity you've gained back.

commentText: Really appreciate your balanced view on things as always. Favourite part of this though was your mention of the joy (or satisfaction) of being deeply involved in problem-solving or refactoring and the feeling of achievement that comes with it.   I think naturally we want to get absorbed in 'deep work' for some of our day - the days when I'm not able to do this, and I'm torn between projects, meetings and piecemeal admin, I tend to end the day a lot more tired and stressed, even if the work itself is less challenging on paper. That's because your brain often craves that bit of extra stimulation, and context-switching takes more out of you. That's the risk we take with AI tooling as well, as it can distance us from the work and problem-solving. I think it's worth stating as well that this isn't just about enjoyment, but using these tools without care an easily weaken a developer's problem-solving mental muscles, which need that practice - and I think this could end up leading to a loss of productivity and developer frustration if that trend continues unchecked.

And of course, it turned out that the AI's answer was missing the point, as so often is the case.  Since there's no escaping management types or the trendies, I'm wondering how to use AI enough so I fit in, but cleverly and minimally enough that I maintain my intellectual strength.  Quite a conundrum!

commentText: I've always enjoyed problem solving, a bit too much in my younger years, because it was on my mind twenty hours a day, even when I was asleep.  I've had my shares of uncertainty in my career, but what's driving me forward is the relentless urge to get to the optimal solution, and once I get there, I will start thinking another one that might exceeds the previous.  I really didn't care where I was, if allowing me to do all these creative work was not called "Tech" but something else, I would go for it.  Everything else that came with it was a bonus, or a downside depending on how you view the countless time you spend on reaching the light-bulb moment.   If people are leaving the tech job, perhaps is not all too bad, maybe they will land on a real job that they have the passion for.  It's hard though, because before you can pursue your passion, you'd need a job that provides you with the basic needs.

commentText: I turned down Microsoft and Amazon recruiters years ago. I knew these huge corporations were trashy places to work and didn't feel like being a cog in the greedy corporate machine. I have never regretted it and have had no problem remaining employed as a well-paid developer working for manufacturing and other non-tech companies. I really don't understand the attraction of working for big tech. It seems like most people seeking to do so have some mental image of sipping lattes and munching avocado toast and having short, no-stress workdays. I think the jobs I've had over the years fit closer to that cushy job idea than the jobs at Google, Microsoft, Amazon and Meta. The people quitting are realizing that. If you're good at your job, most companies reward you for it. Not big tech.

commentText: There are some asterisks in the data that are not being considered. 1. Population growth, in 2000-280M citizens / 2025-350M citizens (this is without considering increased immigration flow) 2. Age bracket, they were not all affected the same way. 3. Qualifications race condition, people are expected to have greater skills than in the past, spending even more resources in education.  What it might seem like a healthy unemployment rate 20 years ago might not apply to today's market. And there's a concept called underemployment that is also important to mention, due to inflation/more printing of money overtime that reduces its value, at the same time the housing costs increases, therefore you have another underreported section that we are not considering. Wages not being able to keep up to the way it's being devalued. (Basically you have to work more to pay for the same thing in the past)

videoTitle: College grads struggle to find jobs
videoDescription: Graduates are entering a turbulent economy, with more competition for entry-level positions. Job postings have declined by 15%, ...
commentText: Okay, here's the thing for many people who think that taking up a trade or having a "useful" degree is far more helpful than getting a supposed "useless" degree. There's no such thing as a useless degree. All jobs has a place in our society, otherwise they won't exist. It's only seen as useless because they're exploited & underpaid.   Of everyone picks up a trade, the issue will still exist. There's not a lot of jobs available for blue collar workers. Many companies have either moved overseas or has replaced their workers with an automated workforce to cut back on labor costs. We've lost a lot of companies here in the United States. Think about how many companies who shut their branches down in different cities that used to be known for welding, coal mining, car manufacturing, clothing manufacturing etc & they were (& still are in some places) struggling? If more people go back to picking up a trade, there's no jobs for everyone.  Also, the job industry sucks. Most of labor companies uses AI to filter through resumes. That's why even if you put through 10, 20, even even more than 200 job applications a day, they won't pick your resume. Not to mention, the rate of people who has the same college degree as you had gone up significantly over the last 20-30 years. Meaning that you're fighting other people who went to Harvard, Yale, Penn University or even local community colleges for the same jobs that doesn't pay very well.   Companies are also putting out fake job listings. "Ghost listings" are everywhere. They do that to make investors think that these companies are growing. When they're not. So no amount of "but you should've went to school for this." "This degree is useless." Blah blah blah will never fix anything. Because it's not an us problem, it's an industry problem.

Don't live paycheck to paycheck.  Live on the cheap and save as much as you can.

commentText: I have a couple of issues with this discussion. First of all, they've completely ignored the elephant in the room. Companies are hedging their bets towards accelerated automation with A.I., whether the predictions pan out or not, hence  the precarious hiring processes. It's all over the news. This doesn't represent the entirety of the problem, but it definitely shouldn't be ignored. The harsh reality is that employees are a financial liability and a necessary evil to business owners, and if a cheaper, more reliable option exists, they will be foaming at the mouth to take it. If you look at the trend of entry level roles requiring say, 8 years of experience for example, that's a tell to indicate they might be automating away the 'true' entry level roles to A.I. So really, these are not entry level roles at all.  Second, Mitch did make a great point about not posting TikTok videos like this. Granted, it's a bad look and I totally agree that it's cringe, but let's be real, social media is so saturated with these videos anymore, nobody cares, really.  And the way we consume media is constantly changing. In 50 years TikTok will probably be replaced with something else ten times over, so the stuff people post today will go the way of polaroid photos, stuffed in a shoebox somewhere, or the digital equivalent. Sure, it's out there. But really, who cares?    Third, farming college graduates into the restaurant industry is probably a bad idea. The whole reason people go to college is so that they can get a professional job that pays a salary and benefits, and have a shot at an actual career trajectory. Part of what causes career stagnation is not landing a job in their field right out of the gate. The more time that passes before they get that first job, the wider the skills gap grows, and the less likely they'll ever escape the gig work grind. So yeah, spending a couple of years waiting tables when you have a degree in engineering could be the death nail for your career. Your education continues with that first job, and without it, you fall behind. That's why internships are such an essential component of the career ladder. You need to keep your education fresh, and if you take too long of a break, it's over.   Lastly, people who quit their job without another one lined up were probably in the wrong job in the first place. Their physical and mental health are likely in the toilet from burnout, so they are in total fight or flight mode. Going to work is becoming physically painful for them. Something like 80% of people are either not satisfied or actively disengaged with their work as it is. If you would rather starve than continue to go to work, that could be a symptom of a much larger and systemic problem. Anyone who can sit there and say, 'Don't quit your job without another one lined up', maybe has some survivorship bias. They're probably one of the lucky few who are actually satisfied with their position in life. I don't necessarily think it's bad advice, but anyone who is set in their mind on quitting their job without a fallback position is already so far gone that simply telling them not to quit is just pushing them to do it all that much faster. It's like reverse psychology. By saying don't jump, you're basically daring them to do it. I just think that a little more validation and understanding for people in this situation is in order here.

We‚Äôre not gonna innovate or hustle our way out of poverty in a fascist state controlled by billionaire oligarchs. Thats a rat race. We should be focused on creating systemic change while we still have some power in the work force. 20-30 years from now we wont have power but right NOW???? WORKING CLASS LABOR is what keeps the economy and market flowing. Cut that flow off and then come with unified demands for citizens. Affordable housing, universal healthcare, free education, livable wages, etc. Best part is that it only takes a small percentage of people to bring the economy to its knees. And UBI is a trap. commentText: It's absolutely true, and not just for those reasons.
